18. **Shipping and Containing**

There are a great many changes, as everything was bought but by a box or barrel by bulk until around 1920 when we began to get wrapped food.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In 1902 when we first homesteaded for breakfast porridge - home cured pork & toast
for dinner corned pork potatoes, milk pudding, eggs
supper pork fried potatoes, hot biscuits, syrup
superb fried apples, sauce

16. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

15. Give the menu, list those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Leg & onion potatoes, wild cranberry sauce, dried apple pie
my husband 34 myself 26, son 3 daughter 6 months, two bachelors, one 33 the other 31

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

So we always had plenty to eat, although much of a variety. As the settlers all came from well settled districts in Manitoba, we brought all our stores & cooking utensils with us & we were only two years without a railway. We were fortunate to be only 3 & 1/2 miles from the village that sprung up when the railway came through. So there was no real hardship to pioneer in this district.
there are a few more things, but I can't remember them all.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates here possible).

There are a great many changes, as everything was bought out of a box or barrel by bulk until around 1920 when we began to get wrapped food.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In 1902 when we first homesteaded for breakfast porridge, home cured pork & toast for dinner, canned pork potatoes, milk pudding, eggs. Supper, pork fried potatoes, hot biscuits, syrup, sugar, dried apples, sauce.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu, list those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Leg & venison potatoes, wild cranberry sauce, dried apple pie.

My husband 34, myself 26, son 3, daughter 6 months, two bachelors, one 33 the other 31.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we always had plenty to eat, although much of a variety. As we settlers all came from well settled areas in Manitoba, we brought all our stores & cooking utensils with us & we were only two years without a railway. We were fortunate to be only 3 & 1/2 miles from the village that sprang up when the railway came through. So there was no real hardship to procure in this district.
there are a great many things, however, that were bought out of a store in Bismarck by buck until around 1902 when we began to get wrapped goods.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the first place there were not the variety of foods to begin with, we had to do considerable planning to make a change. But as you know necessity is the mother of invention.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We have never relied on purchased foods. We have always grown our own. And in 1918 we started canning all kinds of meat, fruit & vegetables, soup, etc., jams, jelly, pickles, etc. In the basement & bring up a whole meal to be replenished. Only potatoes to cook. It is a gas cup from Homestead but we enjoyed it.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I am sorry I can't give you all the answers, and my husband & myself & family are the only settlers left that came in to the district in the first two years. My husband is 82 & I will be 73 next year. Memories are none too good. I would popoming again if I were younger but I would only take apple boxes & no furniture if gets spoiled in transit & that is a heartache.

Sincerely - Elsie Dickie
I am very grateful for your letter.

I am writing to you from our new home in [city]. We have been here for about two weeks now, and we are adjusting well. The weather has been quite pleasant, and we are enjoying the scenery.

We have been busy settling into our new home. We have been able to find some nice neighbors who have been very welcoming. We have also been able to find a good job for my husband, which is helping us to settle in.

We are looking forward to making new friends and exploring our new community. We hope to be able to visit you soon.

Thank you again for your letter.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
